context: However, since the long-term prognosis of leukaemia was relatively poor at the time of the Pliofilm study, the leukaemia incidence should not have been very much higher. Today more leukaemia cases are cured. The studies of Australian (Glass et al., 2003) and Swedish (Järvholm et al., 1997) oil refinery workers were based on incidence data. For ethylene, 1,3-butadiene and propene, the risk estimates are even more uncertain, given that risk estimates are based on the metabolism of these olefins to the carcinogens ethylene oxide and propylene oxide (Viktorin, 1998).Causal, confounding or random? The combination of low exposure and risk estimates extrapolated from high-level exposure, would not suggest a causal association between VOC emissions and leukaemia in our study. Our results are more coherent with those from the Australian petroleum industry, and Swedish oil refinery operators. Even if the exposure levels in the residential area we studied were very low, it is remarkable that we found an elevation of leukaemia in the parishes considered most at risk.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, buta-1,3-diene and propylene oxide are mentioned as metabolites of olefins that can form carcinogenic compounds, specifically ethylene oxide and propylene oxide. The discussion revolves around the uncertainty of risk estimates for leukemia associated with low-level exposure to these volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in oil refinery workers. While both compounds are linked through their metabolic pathways to potential carcinogenic effects, the context does not provide a direct interaction or detailed relationship between them.
